So like I said already,
ZK, the shorthand

for zero-knowledge cryptography,
is going to change the way we interact online. Why is that?

I'm going to talk
about it in a minute. But at a high level,
you can think of it as being able to prove-- it's a technique
to prove something

without revealing why it's true. And it's a fundamentally
game changing paradigm

for the following reason. Like, imagine playing
poker and you're playing-- I don't know how many people
here have played poker--

but the idea is you
draw a hand of cards, and depending on the
makeup of your hand, you can potentially-- certain
hands are better than others.

And you can win a
bet effectively. So for anyone who
doesn't play poker, I think that was a
terrible explanation. But, hopefully, you follow me.

And to make that game work, at
the end of the round of betting, you need to show your
hand to your opponent.

They need to be able to
verify your claim that you have a certain hand of cards. And that's the only way up to--
up until we've, cryptographers,

discovered this technique,
this was the only way to verify that what someone was
claiming was, in fact, true. But with the advent of
zero-knowledge cryptography,

you, basically, now
have the ability to prove that you have
a certain hand of cards without revealing why it's true. It doesn't have a
physical analog.

But it has many,
many applications, both in web3 and in web2.

With that introduction, I'm
going give a short history of ZK and how it came to be,
how did cryptographers

come up with this. So this is not going to
start with a bad dad joke. Although, I do have a large
roster of bad dad jokes.

So cryptographers-- this
problem was motivated by--

I don't want to say laziness-- But maybe a little
bit of laziness on the part of
theoretical cryptographers and mathematicians,
who are constantly

reviewing each other's work. And they're like, OK. Bob down the hall
said he has a proof

for some amazing new theorem
or something like that. I said, well, it's 25 pages.

That's a lot of reading. I want to go have a beer. I want to go do something else. And so do I really have to
read all 25 pages of this

to be convinced that
this work is true. So this is the
theoretical foundation for zero-knowledge
cryptography was this concept
of interactive proofs. It's like, OK. And this is-- I gave you a tangible example.

But this is described
in theory in the papers that talked about IP. But the idea of
IP is, basically,

like, I have a long
transcript and I don't want to read the whole
transcript to you, for you

to understand that I know
what I'm talking about. So you imagine two parties. So one person has a claim. And then the other
party, basically,

asks questions to the
person with the claim. And after a certain
number of rounds, that person can be convinced
that the claim is true,

and the transcript
of the interaction should be shorter than the
statement being proven. That's really the key thing.

That's why I said it was
motivated by not laziness, but, maybe, efficiency. I want to ask some questions
and know whether you're

telling the truth without
necessarily having to read the whole thing myself. So this is called-- this is,
roughly speaking, these are

what interactive proofs are. So in the parlance
of cryptography, we say there's a
prover and a verifier.

The prover is trying
to prove a claim. The verifier is
asking questions. And at the end of
that interaction,

the verifier accepts or rejects. It turns out like, I
don't know-- who here

is a computer science student? Anyone? OK. Cool. What, I think, is the
CS103 is the theory course.

Is that still true? OK. Cool. So it turns out
interactive proofs apply to a gigantic
range of problems.

So IP-- the famous theorem
is IP equals p space for those who have taken CS103. So, basically, for anyone
who's not in the CS curriculum,

you can, basically,
convert many, many types of very hard problems into
an interactive proof problem.

So it's a really, really
interesting result. And it has a lot
of applications. And so with CLDR, for this
talk in the context of ZK,

is that, even though
it's a slightly weird way of referring-- of designing
problems or applications,

you can convert a
lot of applications that we would care
about into this context.

off, which is unfortunate. But this is something what
I already talked about.

This is basically what it is. So Alice is the prover. Bob is the verifier. So Alice claims something. Bob is going to
ask some questions.

This repeats over and over. And then the interaction,
again, the key thing is that the interaction, the
transcript of that interaction is shorter than
the claim itself.

The key properties here
for interactive proofs-- we have completeness, which
is that, everything I can

make a claim about, I can
also prove in this scheme. And soundness is that I cannot
make any false claim that is

verified correctly. And then the
interesting thing here-- and we'll talk about
this in a minute-- is these two claims
are not quite equal.

You should be complete. The proof system should be
complete with 100% certainty,

like, there's absolutely
every statement can be proven. But the soundness
is probabilistic.

So with vanishingly
low probability can anyone generate
a false proof.

And what cryptographers
also realized is that you can actually
apply this idea, which

has no privacy preserving
properties at all. But you can make it
privacy preserving,

if you apply some cryptographic
primitives to this interaction. And this is where the
zero knowledge comes from.

So zero knowledge proofs
have a fundamental intellectual and academic
basis in this work

of interactive proofs. And so this is actually
the original paper,

where this idea was proposed. And so these are two
MIT cryptographers, who ended up winning, I
think, the Turing Award.

And this paper was published,
I believe, in 1980. But the idea was,
like, OK, we have this interesting interactive
proving protocol.

What if we tweak it
a little bit in ways that I'm not going to get into? But I guess the
upshot for everyone

here is that, let's apply
some cryptography to it to make the interaction,
basically, hidden.

And so at the end
of the interaction, someone can come up with a proof
without sharing the transcript and say, hey, this is correct.
This claim is correct. Cool.

This is just more for

in all kinds of flavors.

So interactive proofs plus
this zero-knowledge property is called sigma protocols.

So this is the
original form of ZK. An interesting sigma protocol

Schnorr signature scheme. So Schnorr is used, I think,
now in Bitcoin and in a couple

of other protocols. If you take sigma protocols,
and sigma protocols are inherently interactive.

And you can apply
a technique called Fiat-Shamir, which is,

transcript of a verifier asking

questions by just hashing. You, basically, use
the hash function to give effectively a random--

you randomize a verifiers
list of questions. You can simulate the verifier
with the hash function

effectively. And that gets you
non-interactive zero knowledge arguments. And that's those
are called NIZKs.

And then if you take
NIZKs and apply an emoji-- no, I'm just kidding.

If you take NIZKs

The application of a zk-SNARK

specifically, hashing. So in Ethereum, the
KECCAK hash function is really used all
over the place.

specific hash function is extremely
inefficient to do inside of a zero-knowledge proof.

There are other hash functions
that are much more efficient. But the KECCAK
function, specifically, is just really hard.

the lack of these

The performance overhead--
so one thing you should all be thinking is like, wow, I can

there's no way to
